title: Attacker can read password from log data
vulnerability_information:
## Summary:
Attacker can read plain text password from log data.

## Steps To Reproduce:

  1. From application dashboard choose Users section, I simultaneously ran process hacker to see the process disk write and read behavior.
  2. change the password of one of the users, and you see in process hacker window the place for log data creation.
  3. Open the file in favorite editor in that place:
%UserProfile%\AppData\Local\Temp\tomcat.1470616378544174392.8080\work\Tomcat\localhost\midpoint 

## Supporting Material/References:
I have uploaded a video for POC.

## Impact

Attacker can read plain text password from log data.
vulnerability_information_html:
Summary:

Attacker can read plain text password from log data.

Steps To Reproduce:

  1. From application dashboard choose Users section, I simultaneously ran process hacker to see the process disk write and read behavior.
  2. change the password of one of the users, and you see in process hacker window the place for log data creation.
  3. Open the file in favorite editor in that place: %UserProfile%\AppData\Local\Temp\tomcat.1470616378544174392.8080\work\Tomcat\localhost\midpoint

Supporting Material/References:

I have uploaded a video for POC.

Impact

Attacker can read plain text password from log data.

activities.message:
Thanks for your report @princenullbite,

More information is needed before this report can be adequately reviewed. Is it possible you could provide a clear step-by-step proof-of-concept showing how this can be exploited **against third-parties?**

Thanks again for your report, and hope to hear back from you soon.

Cheers,
@still

activities.message: After changing of the password of one user the changed password stored in log data path of that user other other users of that system can read the plaintext username and password in log data.
activities.markdown_message: After changing of the password of one user the changed password stored in log data path of that user other other users of that system can read the plaintext username and password in log data.

activities.message:
1. In first step login with user Step1.PNG(F458763) 
2. Logout from that user and log data file will create in %UserProfile%\AppData\Local\Temp\tomcat.1470616378544174392.8080\work\Tomcat\localhost\midpoint path.
3. Login again and change the password form user section Step2.PNG(F458764) i have uplaoded tmp files too.
activities.markdown_message:
1. In first step login with user Step1.PNG(F458763)
  2. Logout from that user and log data file will create in %UserProfile%\AppData\Local\Temp\tomcat.1470616378544174392.8080\work\Tomcat\localhost\midpoint path.
  3. Login again and change the password form user section Step2.PNG(F458764) i have uplaoded tmp files too.

activities.message:
Hi @princenullbite,

For this to qualify as an issue, you will have to demonstrate that the password can be extracted without having a foothold on the server where Midpoint is installed. Without this, the report is more of a best practice problem than an actual security issue. 

However, I will ask the team for their input, maybe it is something they would like to have fixed. 

Thanks, 
@ktistai
activities.markdown_message:

For this to qualify as an issue, you will have to demonstrate that the password can be extracted without having a foothold on the server where Midpoint is installed. Without this, the report is more of a best practice problem than an actual security issue.

However, I will ask the team for their input, maybe it is something they would like to have fixed.

Thanks,
@ktistai

activities.message:
Hello @princenullbite,

Sorry about the late from our end, so after further discussion with the Midpoint team we came to the conclusion that the severity of this issue is Low since those files are deleted immediately. Therefore it is not a long-term storage and as such they still agree to do a payout but with a Low severity.

I hope this makes sense, let me know if you have any questions.

Regards,
@nasr0x01
activities.markdown_message:

activities.message:
Hello @princenullbite,

Thank you for your submission! I was able to validate your report, and have submitted it to the appropriate remediation team for review. They will let us know the final ruling on this report, and when/if a fix will be implemented. Please note that the status and severity are subject to change.

Regards,
@nasr0x01

activities.message:
Hello @princenullbite,

Thank you for this report. The team have confirmed your vulnerability as a Low severity impact.

The H1 platform doesn’t allow €URO payments, hence the funky $168.68 amount.

The USD$ conversion for today is 1 United States Dollar equals 0.89 Euro.

Thanks for your help and participating in this program.

Kind Regards
HackerOne

Regards,
@nasr0x01

activities.message:
Hello @princenullbite,

Just got a word that the issue is fixed, security advisory is published:
`https://wiki.evolveum.com/display/midPoint/Security+Advisory%3A+Plain+text+password+in+temporary+files`

If you’re still able to reproduce this issue, please let us know and we will investigate further. 

Thanks!
@nasr0x01
